intro: Crepis racemosa, commonly known as the common mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with hairy, spoon-shaped leaves and small, yellow disk flowers surrounded by white to pale green ray florets. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. Crepis racemosa is an annual or biennial plant that produces achenes with pappus for wind dispersal.
